title: Quiz 1: Epidemiology & Control Principles
description: Foundations of disease patterns, host-agent interaction, and core prevention principles.

questions.question: A disease that occurs in a given population at a constant rate over a period of several years is termed as:
questions.explanation: Endemic diseases are those that are constantly present in a population or region at a steady frequency.
questions.hint: Think of a 'stable' rate over years.

questions.question: The incubation period is the time between infection and the appearance of symptoms and signs of an illness.
questions.explanation: This is the standard medical definition of the incubation period, where the host is unaware of the infection.

questions.question: Which of the following are considered 'Notifiable Diseases' in Kenya? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Cholera, Measles, Plague, and Yellow Fever are among the high-priority diseases that must be reported to health authorities immediately.
questions.hint: Look for diseases with high epidemic potential.

questions.question: Match the disease control measure to its core principle:
questions.explanation: Source measures target the agent/reservoir; Transmission measures target the route; Host measures target susceptibility.
questions.hint: Does it stop the germ, block the path, or strengthen the person?

questions.question: A person who is invaded by a disease-causing micro-organism is called a ___BLANK___, and the process of the organism reproducing and growing is called ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: The person is the host; the growth of the pathogen is the infection.

questions.question: Arrange the stages of clinical infection progression in the correct sequence:
questions.explanation: Progression starts with the silent incubation, moves to mild/invisible sub-clinical, and ends with overt clinical symptoms.

questions.question: What is the term for an individual who suffers from a sub-clinical infection but can still infect others?
questions.explanation: Carriers are dangerous because they show no symptoms but can spread the disease (e.g., HIV, Typhoid).

questions.question: In the 'Disease Triangle', which component refers to the surroundings in which the agent and host live?

richContent.content:
The Epidemiological Triad

Agent ↔ Host ↔ [ ? ]

questions.explanation: The environment consists of physical, biological, and socio-economic factors that affect the balance between host and agent.
questions.hint: It is the third corner of the triad.

questions.explanation: Health centres focus on Information, Education, and Communication (IEC) along with routine vector and water control.
questions.hint: IEC is a core primary health care function.

questions.question: When many non-immune children are born in an area since the last outbreak, a sudden large number of cases occurs. This is called:
questions.explanation: An epidemic occurs when the rate of disease exceeds the normal frequency for that population.
